div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

h1.span: COVID-19 Information

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });
$(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

span.p: Dear ASD families and staff,

This week I am thankful for the rain, as I know it will melt our snow and bring the Alaska spring into view. However, the rain does make it even more difficult to stay in our homes during this time—cloudy days sometimes influence a dreary outlook. If you get the chance, rain or shine, try to get outside for a socially distanced walk with your family. The movement and change of scenery will help to improve everyone’s state of mind!

This week, I am sharing data on our distance learning inputs. This time away from school due to COVID-19 is significant for the young people in our nation. Schools around our country cannot meet the educational goals set when we were all actually IN schools learning. So much of our work and expertise is personal and relational to people and places. Nonetheless, the School Board has asked us to look ahead and capture what we learn from student engagement in schooling right now.

Below are the data for our middle and high school students who have accessed the coursework and turned in an assignment. While not ideal, it is better than most large cities are reporting around the nation. (Way to go freshmen!) At the end of each school year, ASD looks generally at student outcomes to gauge the learning that has taken place. At the end of this year, we will use more of a snapshot on the inputs rather than outputs, as testing will not occur at the end of this school year. For next fall, however, we will take a detailed look at our early learning assessments (grades K-2) and MAP Growth (grades 3-8) to give us a picture of our students’ learning outcomes over the last year.

On a side note, I often joke with my staff that I am a self-professed geek. I share this trait with pride, as I have always loved numbers and research. I apologize if these data are TMI (too much information) for my letter today. My goal is to be transparent with teaching and learning during this time. It is important for us to understand and be candid about what learning may be lost during this final quarter of the school year. That understanding will be critical to overcoming those deficits once we head back to school – in our schools!

p.strong: Middle School Student Engagement as of Friday, April 10

span.p: Grade 6: 78% had logged into Apex, 62% had completed at least one activity
Grade 7: 85% had logged into Apex, 70% had completed at least one activity
Grade 8: 88% had logged into Apex, 76% had completed at least one activity
Average: 72% of middle school students had completed at least one activity

p.strong: High School Student Engagement as of Monday, April 13

span.p: Grade 9: 89% had logged into Canvas, 85% had completed at least one activity
Grade 10: 74% had logged into Canvas, 69% had completed at least one activity
Grade 11: 75% had logged into Canvas, 70% had completed at least one activity
Grade 12: 72% had logged into Canvas, 66% had completed at least one activity
Average: 73% of high school students had completed at least one activity

So much information about COVID-19 and distance schooling has hit your inboxes in the last few weeks. The following questions have come to me from families and students in emails. This information is always good to review and share with everyone.

With much of our learning going online, it is a great time to review cyber safety guidelines with your children. There are three important things to consider for your family’s cyber safety: the technology you use, your household rules, and how you will be monitoring student usage. ASD has created a Safe Computing webpage that addresses these three areas in more detail. It also has a host of resources to help you ensure your child’s online safety.

p.strong: What online safety precautions has ASD put into place?

span.p: The District’s Safe Computing webpage includes many best practices for making your child safe at home. The District has also implemented a number of measures to help keep kids safe while doing online work:

ul.li: Online sharing across District applications is limited to other students and staff.
ASD Chromebook devices have content filtering enabled.
ASD Chromebook devices run the Chrome operating system, which updates regularly and has fewer software risks.
ASD devices and accounts are monitored for hacking and malware.

p.strong: Are there practice programs or other lessons available if my elementary student can do more?

span.p: The District has included a number of additional resources that students and parents can access through https://clever.asdk12.org using their student login information. Lexia Core5 (K-5), PowerUp (6-8), and MathWhizz (K-8) are District-vetted online learning programs available through this platform. These programs adapt to your child’s needs, present content based on their achievement, and provide a more structured practice and learning time. Additionally, at the above portal, parents can download paper packets with practice exercises and activities. Parents can also request delivery of these packets through their student’s teacher.

Next week, the District will begin a program for intermediate students to enroll in online courses that offer more scope, sequence, and content. This action is in response to the Governor extending the school closures. The program will also have accountability measures for parents to understand their child’s learning progress.

p.strong: When can we get the things from my child’s desk/locker?

span.p: We are in the process of creating a plan for kids to collect their belongings from schools that will adhere to social distancing guidelines. Schools will be contacting students within the next couple of weeks with details. It will be critical for families to follow their school’s plan closely to help ensure everyone’s safety during this process.

I want to share one more important resource…the number 742-HELP. This is the number to our one-stop helpline at ASD. Questions posed are quickly directed to the department which can provide assistance. No question is too big or small! We will work to do whatever we can to support our educational community. Have a great weekend. I am getting off my computer now — to take a walk outside!
Sincerely,

Deena M. Bishop, Ed.D.
Superintendent, Anchorage School District

5530 E. Northern Lights Boulevard
Anchorage, Alaska 99504
Office Phone (907) 742-4312

h1.span: Apr. 10: Message from the Superintendent

div.p: Dear ASD families and staff,

We have made it—two weeks of “school at home!” And by now you’re likely aware that the Governor has extended the current school building closure through the end of the school year. For ASD, the plan to continue school at home, through a variety of online and virtual applications as well as more traditional paper curriculum packets, will remain largely unchanged through the end of the school year. I’ve heard so many inspiring examples of how teachers and students are coming together virtually to connect and continue learning. Keep up what you’re doing! It WILL make a difference!

One way to look at this school closure extension is that it adds a degree of predictability and consistency to the rest of the school year. Students and teachers will not have to endure the disruption of reopening schools again after being away for nearly two months. Instead, everyone can remain focused on the current game plan and make the most of it.

The Governor’s mandate to continue social distancing also means that graduation ceremonies, as we know them, will not be possible this year. ASD leadership is actively exploring a range of options to honor our graduating seniors and to provide them the celebration they deserve. Once we have a more complete picture, we will share the various ways we will honor our seniors’ tremendous accomplishments. I’m confident our community will come together and make this event special. It won’t be the same, but it will be special.

So much of what I want to express has been said over and over. I know that saying “uncharted waters” is simply passé as ASD has been in this world crisis for more than a month. And, while I am generally a cheerful person, I do not want to seem like an ASD Pollyanna. Things are not all effortless and sweet. Nonetheless, I have such appreciation and am in total awe of your collective work. It is humbling to me.
So, I want to check in with you on other things…

ul.li: Are you more exhausted than ever before as you work and study from home? I am.
Do you have a renewed interest in purchasing an ergonomic chair or desk that seemed like an excessive purchase in the past? I do.
Did you ever think about going back to school or your classroom to take a break from your “work or school at home?” I have.

div.p: How about these things…

ul.li: Have you discovered that a walk in the sun, even in chilly conditions, warms the heart? I have.
Do you now see the people in your neighborhood through your windows (distancing themselves, of course)? I do.
Did you know Netflix saves your shows just where you left off, even when your kids mess with the control? I do, now.
Have you cleaned something or organized a closet while you have been home? My kids have.
Have you found the perfect mate for which to hunker at home? I have.
Have you learned something about each of your family members that you never realized before? I certainly have.

div.p: The global pandemic has changed our present world so much. Yet, being in this situation has connected us to the goodness of others and reacquainted us to the simplicity of life.
Many have paid huge debts in the past for our freedoms. Today, I am proud that we, ASD, are willing to pay those sacrifices forward.
Sincerely,

Deena M. Bishop, Ed.D.
Superintendent

h1.span: Apr. 3: Message from the Superintendent

div.p: Dear ASD staff, students, and families,

I want to say thanks for your diligence in getting through this week of learning many new things! In some ways, this felt like the first week of school again as everyone worked to build their muscles in our new way of conducting “school.”
By now, teachers across the District have connected with their students via Zoom, Canvas, Seesaw, and APEX online learning platforms.

We are concerned about the security and safety of students and staff while online, especially in Zoom. A new protocol was established last week in which ASD’s meetings are invite only, meaning that students and staff must use their ASD password protected account, not a personal one. When each online class begins, students are approved to enter the online environment, and the tools for the session are all controlled by the host, not the participants. Again, permission must be granted. These controls are designed to keep our staff and students safe online.

However, more vigilance is needed. While Zoom, the company, has responded to the security concerns, ASD continues to have students disrupt the learning environment with poor behaviors. Sharing passwords, filming sessions, filtering the media, and displaying inappropriate behaviors while in Zoom class are unwarranted. ASD will address these behaviors appropriately as we do with misbehaviors in our traditional classrooms. Again, cyber misconduct will not be tolerated. We encourage our students to channel their creativity productively, not disruptively. More information for staff to this regard will be going out early next week.

For ASD courses, as a review to our students and parents, schools have been asked to do a phased roll out, with the first two weeks focused on the core subjects of English Language Arts and Math for all grades, and additionally, Science and Social Studies for high school. High school electives courses will begin April 13. For parents, students, and teachers, our collective school from home reality is new. We are taking one bite of the education apple at a time you could say! Thanks for being patient with expectations as teaching and working from home are big actions to juggle in all our lives. Our employees and our parents are both working through the home issues of the challenges COVID-19 has presented. It is good to go slow to go fast later.

As shared before, two of our main priorities for the remainder of this school year are to keep our seniors on track to graduate and all high school students earning credits. We will provide supplemental educational activities for our elementary and middle school students to sustain them until traditional classroom learning is once again a reality.

In summary, one of the best parts about distance learning is that you work at your own pace, in your own place, and your own space! Parents, please encourage all students to participate with focus. Teachers will be providing feedback on our students’ learning.

In rolling out our distance learning plan, ASD has been mindful that not all students have access to computers or the internet. To plan for equity of our students, we have made several efforts to narrow this gap by issuing Chromebook computers and 750 Wi-Fi hot spots to those high school students who identified a need. As with instruction, we are also rolling out devices in phases. Beginning next week, we will distribute Chromebooks to middle school students who reported a need. To support students without a computer or internet access at the elementary level, we will periodically mail paper/pencil packets on learning units directly to your home. Please share your needs with your teachers, as this will direct the district-wide support.

p.strong: Students with Special Needs in Distance Learning

div.p: We have a clear plan to address individual needs and have been reaching out to families to discuss their students’ unique needs. ASD recognizes flexibility and creativity may be required to accommodate and work through individual issues, but we are committed to provide for the needs of our students. Please know that because of the circumstances brought on by COVID-19, we are unable to exactly duplicate the services your children experienced at school, but I assure you that we will do our very best to provide the most comprehensive services and best experiences possible for your children.

p.strong: ASD Engagement in Community-wide Response to COVID-19

div.p: Although the vast majority of ASD employees are working from home and practicing social distancing, ASD is fully engaged and integrated in the community-wide response to COVID-19. To this end, many of our employees are working on the front lines, providing key support to our community. They include our school nurses, food service staff, bus drivers, and maintenance and custodial staff.

We continue to operate 26 fixed feeding sites and six mobile feeding routes to provide free meals to ASD students. We are distributing an average of more than 10,000 meals per day, and three times as many on Fridays! We could not accomplish this without the selfless dedication of our food service staff and bus drivers.

Sixty of our school nurses are volunteering for a variety of essential tasks with the Anchorage Health Department, the municipal Emergency Operations Center, and answering 2-1-1 calls. Some have also been trained to work at mobile testing sites as needed.
ASD has contributed a variety of personal protective equipment (PPE) to community first responders from our emergency supply and relocation sites. These include:
· More than 41,000 M95 masks
· 1,300 surgical masks
· Almost 1,800 bottles of hand sanitizer
· Almost 20,000 pairs of gloves

We are in this together and I am confident in the resiliency and resolve of the entire community. Parents, I encourage you to exercise grace and set realistic expectations for your children. Students, please recognize that most parents are not professional teachers, and they need grace too. Do your best and reach out to your teachers or counselor if you need assistance.

ASD teachers have your best interest in mind. I believe in our teachers who have worked to make school happen, from your homes and our teachers’ homes, in just two short weeks. We are local, we are personal, and we know your children. If your school cannot get the supports you need academically or otherwise, ASD has a created new resource tool for city-wide coordination—the Student and Family Wellness Initiative. This is a one stop access to cooperative resources during this pandemic. If you have a need, we will work within our means as well as with community partners to support it!

Finally, this weekend, I am reminding everyone—teachers, support staff, parents, students, and our community—take a deep breath, try to relax, and remember the most important priority is the health and safety of us all! The choice to succeed is ours to make.
Sincerely,
Deena M. Bishop, Ed.D.
Superintendent, Anchorage School District
5530 E. Northern Lights Boulevard
Anchorage, Alaska 99504
Office Phone (907) 742-4312

h1.aria-label: Mar. 23: COVID-19 Video Message from Dr. Bishop
h1.span: Mar. 23: COVID-19 Video Message from Dr. Bishop

h1.aria-label: Mar. 20: Statement Regarding Closure Extension through May 1
h1.span: Mar. 20: Statement Regarding Closure Extension through May 1

div.p: Dear ASD Families and Staff,

This afternoon, Gov. Dunleavy announced that he is extending the statewide school closure through May 1 in a continued effort to promote social distancing and keep all Alaskans safe. This time will allow school districts across the state to more fully develop an effective method of remote learning. For ASD, this means we will continue our planning to deliver remote learning options for all levels. At this time, we are on track to begin introducing a limited set of these options to students on March 31. Until then, there are educational resources on our website to keep kids’ minds active and learning.

p.strong: Progress on Planning for Elementary Students:

div.p: Parents are always the child’s first and most important teachers. At ASD, we recognize that parents are our primary support during the elementary grades. Current plans for pre-K – grade 6 include districtwide core instructional modules created for all teachers, with supplemental activities designed by individual teachers. Each school will offer live online tutoring supports for both students and teachers, in addition to technical support hotlines. While we will prioritize English Language Arts and Math, teachers will still offer supplemental subject areas as they choose. We will offer elementary support materials in both electronic versions and paper/pencil packets. Times and locations for pickup of paper/pencil packets will be announced in the near future.

p.strong: Progress on Planning for Middle School Students:

div.p: In the middle grades, parents are essential partners in supporting the schools’ instructional efforts and helping monitor student work. Current plans for middle school students in grades 6-8 include a combination of online coursework and supplemental teacher-created activities using two online platforms: Canvas and APEX. While English Language Arts and Math will be a priority, other elective supplemental activities will also be offered.

p.strong: Progress on Planning for High School Students:

div.p: In high school, students are moving to independence and preparing for success in life. Therefore, our initial course offerings focus primarily on courses that are required for graduation. Priority will be given to seniors so as not to disrupt their post-high school plans. Other electives will be offered as we are able to build those units in the Canvas online platform. We plan to offer extended time during the summer for students still needing credits to graduate. We understand our students are preparing for colleges and the workforce, so ASD will continue to support their transition by assisting students with transcripts, scholarship applications, etc.

Our staff will reach out to each family to ensure that individual needs can be met. We recognize that flexibility and creativity may be required to accommodate and work through individual issues in meeting these students’ unique needs.

It is our goal that all high school students have access to the proper technology, starting with seniors to ensure that graduation plans are not interrupted. Once high school students have the devices and connections they need to successfully engage in the coursework, we will then work on middle school technology needs. Local internet companies have already offered to provide free services and/or upgrades, so check the website for further information.
We are grateful for your patience while we work to develop the student, parent, and staff supports and training necessary to roll out such an ambitious effort.

As mentioned, the District has already made a variety of supplemental learning materials accessible for parents, guardians, and students to keep them engaged across a range of subjects. In many cases, teachers have already reached out to students and parents to support them with ideas and activities during this planning period.

ASD Student Nutrition and Transportation services will continue to provide free meals to our students who need them at designated schools and bus routes, and our dedicated school nurse staff will continue providing essential health care services.

I want our students to know that we will be sending a more detailed update on spring sports and activities next week. Additionally, to our employees, please know that we will update you soon on our work plans moving forward. Our goal is to keep our students engaged and our staff gainfully employed for the reminder of the school year.

I continue to be impressed by the ingenuity, compassion, and unconditional commitment our ASD team has shown the last three weeks. Our ability to come together as a team and do what’s right by our students, families, and community is truly astounding.
Sincerely,
Deena M. Bishop, Ed.D.
Superintendent, Anchorage School District

h1.aria-label: Mar. 18: Statement to Families Regarding ASD Services
h1.span: Mar. 18: Statement to Families Regarding ASD Services

div.p: Dear ASD families,
In consideration of the March 17 COVID-19 Health Mandate by Governor Dunleavy this morning I have asked supervisors to send employees home to telework until further notice.

Based on the new guidance, the District wants to ensure it is doing everything possible to protect staff and prevent the spread of this virus. The District recognizes it plays a big role in flattening the curve of COVID-19, and we believe allowing as many staff as possible to work from home is the most responsible action.

ASD leadership will use today to assess the situation and determine further actions moving forward. The District will be conducting a needs assessment with employees to assist in determining the District’s actions to meet our educational goals and mission moving forward.
This new change may limit in-person interaction between ASD staff members and the public. The intent, again, is to protect our staff and to do everything possible to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

p.strong: What ASD services will remain available?

div.p: For students requiring nursing support, please coordinate with ASD Health Services at 907-742-4136 or email healthcareservices@asdk12.org. The District wants to provide any support possible to students who may be high risk according to CDC guidelines.

ASD Student Nutrition will continue food distribution of pre-packaged breakfast and lunch meals for any child 18 or younger at established food service sites. Mobile food service routes will remain scheduled to accommodate students and families unable to access the school distribution sites. Information on feeding sites and mobile bus route meal drop off can be found here.

Over these two weeks, ASD is focusing on supplemental learning activities for students. This will not take the place of regular classroom instruction, and therefore assignments will not be required or graded during this time. However, they are important, and we encourage you to engage in learning with your child. The Family Resources link on the ASD COVID-19 website includes Educational Resources. This is meant to give families ideas and activities that they can do at home during the two-week closure. In addition to the District website, teachers will share supplemental learning activities with their students and families.

ASD teachers have been working hard connecting with their students and families to assess readiness to continue educational activities during the school closure period. As of today, ASD staff has logged over 41,000 phone calls to families!
This is what you told us:

ul.li: 91 percent of households report adequate childcare during school closure time
87 percent of households have high speed internet at home
4 percent have no internet at home

div.p: In regard to devices:

ul.li: 41 percent have a desktop computer at home
70 percent have a laptop computer at home
57 percent have a tablet at home
69 percent have smartphone with data
5 percent have no devices at home
65 percent can print at home

div.p: Evidenced by the data, some families have multiple devices. We will use this information moving forward should we need to develop longer-term plans for distance learning across the District.

As you know, the situation continues to change at a rapid pace, so thank you for your patience. ASD will continue to provide the most current information through its website. I am confident we will persevere through this time, and perseverance is a great asset for our students to learn in today’s world.
Thank you,

Dr. Deena Bishop
Superintendent

h1.aria-label: Mar. 17: ASD Student Nutrition Food Distribution Update
h1.span: Mar. 17: ASD Student Nutrition Food Distribution Update

div.p: Dear ASD Families,

For families needing school food services, ASD Student Nutrition will provide free, pre-packaged breakfast and lunch meals weekdays through Friday, March 27, from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Food will be available for any child 18 years of age or younger at established food service sites. Students are encouraged to pick up meals, if they are unable then parents may pick up for them.

ASD staff will greet students upon arrival and accompany them to receive their pre-packaged breakfast and lunch meals. Small groups will be maintained throughout the process to minimize the gathering of crowds as students receive their take-home meals.
School Sites Distributing Meals as of March 18, 2020:

br.a: Bus Stop Locations For ROUTE 1 SUSITNA-MULDOON FOOD SERVICE ROUTES

br.br:
11:07 a.m. Halligan Street @ Halligan Cross Street

12:13 p.m. Popcary Drive @ Bryan Way South
12:38 p.m. Ptarmigan Court @ Havitur Way
1:01 p.m. 905 Muldoon Rangeview Space 33
1:23 p.m. 705 Muldoon Road Rangeview Trailer Court @ Space 200
1:44 pm 705 Muldoon Road Rangeview Space 35

br.br:
11:04 a.m. 320/340 Bragaw Street
11:25 a.m. 360 Bragaw Street @ The Office
11:49 a.m. Paul Lalone Drive @ James Drive
12:10 p.m. James Drive @ Henry Drive
12:32 p.m. Krista Circle @ Jeannie Court North
12:53 p.m. Columbine Street @ Krista Circle @ mailboxes
1:14 p.m. Krista Circle @ James Drive South
1:35 p.m. Karen Drive @ Robin Drive

p.a: Bus Stop Locations For ROUTE 3 KLATT FOOD SERVICE ROUTES

p.br:
10:23 a.m. Cameo Street @ Aquamarine Circle
10:44 a.m. Turquoise Street @ Carnelian Street
11:05 a.m. Turquoise Street @ Lazuli Street
11:25 a.m. Ruby Street @ Turquoise Street
11:46 a.m. Lazuli Street @ Gem Place
12:06 p.m. Carnelian Street @ Lazuli Street
12:27 p.m. Cameo Street @1044
12:48 p.m. Carnelian Street, no intersection
1:08 p.m. Carnelian Street @ Opal Drive
1:23 p.m. Kasolite Street @ Garnet Street
1:38 p.m. Garnet Street @ Topaz Street
1:52 p.m. Crystal Street @ Kasolite Drive

div.p: For additional details, maps and resources, please visit www.asdk12.org/foodservices
Sincerely,
Anchorage School District

h1.aria-label: Mar. 16: ASD Education Center Closed to the Public
h1.span: Mar. 16: ASD Education Center Closed to the Public

div.p: Due to Governor Dunleavy’s emergency declaration on March 13 announcing the closure of Alaska schools and several public buildings through March 30, the ASD Education Center will be closing its doors to the general public today through March 30.

Visitors/callers to the Ed Center will be asked to call 742-4000, where front desk staff will route visitors/callers to the appropriate department to coordinate a time to speak or meet with a receiving staff member.

h1.span: Mar. 13: Flattening the COVID-19 Curve

div.p: Update: Since this letter was published, Gov. Dunleavy issued a COVID-19 Health Mandate, announcing all scheduled public school days between Monday, March 16, 2020 and March 30, 2020 will be nonstudent contact days in which students will not be attending school.
Update: Since this letter was published, school sites have been added to the original list of food distribution sites - Chugiak Elementary, Homestead Elementary, Ursa Major Elementary (starting 3/18)
Dear ASD Families,
As you may know, the Anchorage School District announced a school closure yesterday, extending spring break for one week for our students.

As of March 12, there has been one confirmed case of COVID-19 in Anchorage. We have carefully considered the risk and impact in the event additional cases are identified in the coming days. We believe it is our responsibility to flatten the curve of additional cases within the community, with the ultimate goal to resume regular operations in the District as soon as possible.

p.em: Image courtesy of Anchorage Health Department.

div.p: We estimate thousands of staff and students anticipate returning from outside of the state over the coming days, and we have carefully considered the potential risk and impact an outbreak could have on ASD and our community.

Our primary goal for next week is to take assessment of our student body and to strengthen our capacity to provide supplemental learning resources that meet the needs of each and every student. By the end of next week, we will have a better understanding of circumstances to make subsequent decisions if the present state of the pandemic expands in our city.

School doors will generally be locked on Monday, March 16. Please remain at home next week. School nurses will call families of all students having medications at school to see if they need to pick up the medications for home use. If yes, the pick up will be by appointment.

For families utilizing school food services, ASD Student Nutrition will provide free food beginning Monday, March 16 through Friday, March 20, from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Food will be available for any child 18 years of age or younger at established food service sites. ASD staff will greet students upon arrival and accompany them to receive their pre-packaged breakfast and lunch meals. Small groups will be maintained in the process to minimize the gathering of crowds as students receive their take-home meals. During the week of March 16, meals will be available at the following distribution sites:

ul.li: Ursa Major Elementary (starting 3/18)

div.p: Should the closure extend beyond the week of March 16, the District will establish routing capabilities to distribute meals to students in their neighborhoods, similar to bus stop services.

Teachers will spend Tuesday and Wednesday reaching out to families to gain more understanding of needs in preparation for supplemental learning and other supports that may be needed while schools are closed. If you have more than one child enrolled at ASD, you may receive more than one call. Again, student meals will be distributed at sites indicated above on Tuesday and Wednesday.

Thursday and Friday will be used as a time for teachers to plan and build capacity for distance learning needs. We plan to supplement learning beginning March 23 if the closure is extended. Student meals will be distributed at the sites indicated above on Thursday and Friday as well.

Please note, the closure includes a suspension of all ASD events and rental facilities effective Monday, March 16, 2020. It is possible this suspension could extend further based on the changing circumstances associated with COVID-19.
The District encourages families to stay informed and to use the extended spring break to practice and promote healthy habits as outlined by the CDC and the list of helpful resources below.

li.a: Facts about novel coronavirus and how to prevent COVID-19 from the SeattleTimes
CDC COVID-19 Checklist for Teachers, Parents, and Administrators

ul.li: Alaska 211 is a free, local resource. Healthcare professionals are available 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Friday, though they are closed noon to 1 p.m. for lunch. Professionals are available to speak with members of the community and answer any questions they have.

li.a: CDC information for People at Risk for Serious Illness from COVID-19

ul.li: The ASD COVID-19 information site continues to host the most up-to-date information from the District in league with our heath partners at CDC, DHSS, and the Anchorage Health Department. Please check your email and/or the ASD website for the most accurate and up-to-date information from the District.

div.p: These are exceptional times. Thank you in advance as we work together on the challenges that the COVID-19 virus have presented. I am confident in the resilience of our community and our outstanding students and families to learn through this together.
Thank you,

Dr. Deena Bishop
Superintendent

h1.aria-label: Mar. 12: Statement from Dr. Bishop, Superintendent, regarding School Closure
h1.span: Mar. 12: Statement from Dr. Bishop, Superintendent, regarding School Closure

div.p: The Anchorage School District (ASD) is announcing a school closure, extending spring break for one week, for our students. Detailed guidance for District employees will be released tomorrow. I want to be clear that it is possible that the closure of our schools could be extended due to changing circumstances. Please know this closure is to prepare for delivery of alternative education if that becomes necessary.

This announcement is informed by the evolving COVID-19 situation and our understanding that many students, families, and staff members are returning from travels around the world. It also comes with very deliberate consideration of our mission and safety of our students and staff, as well as for the protection of our community.

Understanding that over 50,000 students and staff enter our schools and offices daily has weighed heavily into this decision. When school is in session, more than one out of six members of our community interact in close proximity to each other in the classroom environment. Schools are places for large gatherings of young people. While youth seem to be resilient to the COVID-19 virus, we know that youth can, and will, interact with higher risk community members. No other entity in our city is better able to flatten the curve and potentially impede the spread of COVID-19 than ASD. We can affect a change. And we are choosing to do so.

Similar to staff, our families will be notified with more detailed information tomorrow morning. As mentioned, ASD staff will also be notified directly. The individual functions of our employee groups will be addressed respectively. District staff will work next week to organize and plan for a longer-term closure if needed. ASD will use next week to reach out to every family, student by student, to assess needs, and to plan accordingly.

These are exceptional times. I am confident in the resilience of our District, our city, and our outstanding students and families to get through this together. Thank you in advance to our community as we work as partners to plan for and deal with the uncertainty that the COVID-19 virus has presented our district, city, state, nation, and the world at large.

h1.aria-label: Mar. 11: ASD Families Return from Spring Break
h1.span: Mar. 11: ASD Families Return from Spring Break

div.p: Dear ASD Families,

I hope you are having a great spring break. As you enjoy the last days of vacation, please know that we in ASD are reflecting on the many turn of events in our community and worldwide in regard to COVID-19. Today the World Health Organization categorized COVID-19 as a pandemic. In addition, Governor Dunleavy has declared Alaska in a State of Emergency. Given these declarations, we want to reach out and share school district updates.

At this time, school is NOT canceled for next week. Nevertheless, the status of the virus is dynamic and information is learned day by day. The school district has the intention to notify by Friday if a cancellation is called either at an individual site or districtwide. We encourage you to consider and plan for a longer term (extended spring break) in case ASD will need to enact social distancing (the practice of not congregating in large groups of people). Distancing creates the hope of lessening the impact of COVID-19 in our schools, community, and our state. The primary question I am receiving is about school cancelation. The call for an extended time off and school to be delivered alternatively will be made in accordance with health authorities and best practices in containing the virus.

I would like to reiterate that as of March 11, 2020, there are ZERO confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Alaska. However, with more than 50,000 individuals walking in and out of our doors daily, ASD makes up a large amount of our community. We have a responsibility to model preventative measures. Therefore, in alignment with our restriction on international travel and out-of-state travel, ASD is suspending all travel within the state for students and employees through April 2020. School personnel will follow up with students and families on the trips canceled at each site.

If your children are sick, please keep them home and practice social distancing in our community. We will continue to practice good handwashing, suspend hand shaking in our schools, as well as suspend food sharing that is not prepackaged. We, in ASD, will also model best practices and take responsibility to prevent discrimination or stigmatization by only sharing accurate information.

In accordance with CDC recommendations, if your child has a pre-existing health condition or is medically fragile, we encourage you to keep him or her home. This is essential for the safety of your child. Additionally, if you have traveled outside Alaska over the break to countries identified by the CDC as Level 3, please follow the CDC guidelines requiring travelers to stay home for 14 days after returning to the United States and practice social distancing.
Thank you for coming together as a community to support one another in this time of uncertainty. You will receive another communication from ASD on Friday, March 13, 2020.

Sincerely,
Deena Bishop
Superintendent

h1.aria-label: Mar. 10: ASD Staff: Prevention, Sanitization, and Preparation
h1.span: Mar. 10: ASD Staff: Prevention, Sanitization, and Preparation

p.strong: As information around COVID-19 develops, we will update staff information. Today, please see the updates which are provided in the prevention measures as well as actions for a suspected case. Please share your questions and concerns with your supervisors. ASD is remaining current on the COVID-19 topic and will always communicate updates with you.

div.p: Dear ASD Staff,

Yesterday, ASD sent a letter to our families with information on actions they can take to prepare should COVID-19 make its way to Alaska. Today’s letter is intended to provide more guidance to you with specific information on what the District is doing to prepare for a potential outbreak of the virus. The District’s planning and preparation will continue during Spring Break; nevertheless, the information below is helpful in preparing you to leave for break as well as for your return.

Prevention Measures – ASD continues to operate as usual, and schools should do their best to maintain regular educational routines. At this time, there is no need to cancel assemblies or limit large gatherings of students. ASD will follow the guidance of the Municipality and the State in determining whether or not to limit or restrict large gatherings.

p.span: Symptoms of COVID-19 may appear 2-14 days after exposure and could include fever, cough, and shortness of breath. Please refer to the CDC COVID-19 website or call Alaska 2-1-1 for the most current information on symptoms.

div.p: The best defense against any contagious illness is frequent and effective handwashing. Based on guidance from healthcare professionals, masks are not recommended for adults or children unless specifically coordinated with the school nurse. Below are the items we included in our letter to families which describe our actions.

ul.li: Teach proper hand washing.
Use hand sanitizer if soap and water are not available.
Only use ASD provided or approved sanitization products when cleaning offices or classrooms (no homemade cleaning solutions).
Suspend handshaking routines.
Educate all staff on current protocols.
Suspend attendance awards.
Stay home when sick.

div.p: Spring Break Sanitization – During spring break, ASD Operations crews will be in schools disinfecting surfaces. Special emphasis will be placed on all high-touch surfaces such as desks, chairs, bathroom fixtures, lockers, doorknobs, etc. These crews will use the quaternary disinfectant that is presently used on a daily basis. They will also be using new electrostatic sprayers to dispense a hospital grade, non-toxic disinfectant.

Before departing for the break, all staff should clear off desks and tables to allow crews to fully clean these surfaces. Keep in mind that custodial staff will not move your personal items left on these surfaces. Employees should take what they need over the break with them.

School staff members who come into their building during the break may encounter the custodial crews at work. Please be accommodating, as the custodians cannot ‘skip your room’ while you are on the premises. This would interrupt the work flow and slow progress.

Staff members who are in the buildings may notice a faint chemical odor of bleach, although the product is not traditional bleach. This product is non-toxic and has been fully vetted by the District. Any odor associated with this cleaning effort is temporary and will dissipate long before the break is over. If the odor should bother anyone, the best course of action would be to exit the building and return at a later time.
Crews will also be sanitizing all buses during the break.

Actions for a Suspected Case of COVID-19 – If a student or staff member is suspected of having the virus or is believed to have been exposed (referred to as a Person Under Investigation or PUI), school nurses and health services are prepared.
Upon identifying a PUI, the following actions will be taken by the school nurse or member of the health services team:

ol.li: School or building will be placed in Stay Put.
PUI will be immediately isolated in any available room and given a mask to wear.
School nurse will put on a gown, mask, gloves, and eye protection.
Only the school nurse should have contact with the isolated PUI.
Nurse or administrator will contact ASD Health Services.

li.span: Depending on recommendations and patient status:
The parent/patient will be asked to call their medical home (Health Services will assist)
Transport will be coordinated by Health Services (if no ride is available)

ol.li: School will remain in Stay Put until PUI is transported.
Do not engage the media. Refer media to ASD Communications (742-4151 or x4153).
Wait at least two hours before reentering the isolation room.
The District and school leadership will determine the next steps. (parent / community notification, school disinfection, etc.

div.p: Travel Considerations - Due to the risk of contracting the virus or being isolated outside of Alaska, ASD has canceled all school-sponsored domestic and international travel for students and staff through April 2020. In-state travel is not affected. ASD will re-evaluate travel for May and the summer based on new information over time. ASD staff looking to schedule work-related travel should book refundable tickets and be mindful of cancellation dates and policies for airline tickets, conferences, tours, and other activities.

During spring break, many of you have personal vacation plans. If you are traveling, we encourage you to stay current with the latest travel advisories and the specific status of your travel location. The CDC and the Department of State travel pages have reliable and accurate information. Travelers will be subject to any restrictions and isolation requirements that pertain to the country from which they are traveling. Below are some actions to help mitigate travel-related issues:

ul.li: Monitor travel advisories.
Plan for long-term stays.
Communicate with your principal or supervisor regularly.
Welcome students back to school.
Be flexible with missed assignments.
Reduce stigma related to travel locations.
Manage fear and misinformation.

div.p: Discrimination Related to COVID-19 - In schools, we must continue to demonstrate compassion and care, as our greater community navigates this global health situation. We would never want any of our students to be singled out or mistreated based on their ethnicity or where they have traveled. This is unacceptable and contrary to our values. Help us prevent discrimination or stigmatization by sharing accurate information. COVID-19 infection is not connected to any race, ethnicity, or nationality. Misinformation about this virus or its spread can create fear and hostility that harms people and makes it harder to keep everyone healthy.

District Closure Preparation - In an extreme situation, the District may need to close for a time. If a closure takes place, we want everyone to be prepared. ASD has an Infectious Disease Plan in place that will guide the response. That plan can be found at ASD’s COVID-19 landing page.

If the District were to close, the effects to families and staff would be significant. Employees should take the time to consider how a potential closure would impact their daily lives and take steps to plan ahead. Childcare, work/activity schedules, and other logistics are a few areas that may be affected if ASD is forced to close. In the event of a closure, many District functions will still continue. ASD is working to identify these functions and the employees who will continue working through the closure. We ask that you review the following actions related to a potential closure as they pertain to your role within the District:

ul.li: Stay informed through employee communication channels (email, ASD website).
Communicate with supervisors and/or school community.
Be open to remote work opportunities as needed.
Engage e-learning opportunities (school dependent).
Plan for persona absences outside of ASD closure.
Maintain facilities so they are ready when the District reopens.

div.p: You may find these websites useful in your effort to stay informed:

li.a: Alaska Department of Health and Social Services

div.p: I’ve also attached several helpful informational resources to include a very cool handwashing video created by Certified Nursing Assistant students at King Tech High School. I hope you find them useful.

ASD will continue to keep you updated. Thank you for everything you do for students and families across the District. Have a restful and well-deserved spring break. We look forward to everyone’s safe return.
Sincerely,

Deena M. Bishop, Ed.D.
Superintendent, Anchorage School District

5530 E. Northern Lights Boulevard
Anchorage, Alaska 99504
Office Phone (907) 742-4312

h1.aria-label: Mar. 05: ASD Staff: Prevention, Sanitization, and Preparation
h1.span: Mar. 05: ASD Staff: Prevention, Sanitization, and Preparation

p.span: Dear ASD Staff,

Yesterday, ASD sent a letter to our families with information on actions they can take to prepare should COVID-19 make its way to Alaska. Today’s letter is intended to provide more guidance to you with specific information on what the District is doing to prepare for a potential outbreak of the virus. The District’s planning and preparation will continue during Spring Break; nevertheless, the information below is helpful in preparing you to leave for break as well as for your return.

ASD continues to operate as usual, and schools should do their best to maintain regular educational routines. At this time, there is no need to cancel assemblies or limit large gatherings of students. ASD will follow the guidance of the Municipality and the State in determining whether or not to limit or restrict large gatherings.

The best defense against any contagious illness is frequent and effective handwashing. Based on guidance from healthcare professionals, masks are not recommended for adults or children unless specifically coordinated with the school nurse. Below are the items we included in our letter to families which describe our actions.

li.span: Teach proper hand washing.
Use hand sanitizer if soap and water are not available.
Only use ASD provided or approved sanitization products when cleaning offices or classrooms (no homemade cleaning solutions).
Suspend handshaking routines.

Stay home when sick.

p.span: During spring break, ASD Operations crews will be in schools disinfecting surfaces. b.span: Actions for a Suspected Case of COVID-19 –

p.span: If a student or staff member is suspected of having the virus or is believed to have been exposed (referred to as a Person Under Investigation or PUI), school nurses and health services are prepared.
Upon identifying a PUI, the following actions will be taken by the school nurse or member of the health services team:

li.span: School or building will be placed in Stay Put.
PUI will be immediately isolated in any available room and given a mask to wear.
School nurse will put on a gown, mask, gloves, and eye protection.
Only the school nurse should have contact with the isolated PUI.
Nurse or administrator will contact ASD Health Services.
PUI will be escorted out of the building and transported to Providence Hospital with assistance from the Municipality of Anchorage.
School will remain in Stay Put until PUI is transported.
Do not engage the media. Refer media to ASD Communications (742-4151 or x4153).
Wait at least two hours before reentering the isolation room.
The District and school leadership will determine the next steps. (parent / community notification, school disinfection, etc.

p.span: Due to the risk of contracting the virus or being isolated outside of Alaska, ASD has canceled all school-sponsored domestic and international travel for students and staff through April 2020. In-state travel is not affected. ASD will re-evaluate travel for May and the summer based on new information over time. ASD staff looking to schedule work-related travel should book refundable tickets and be mindful of cancellation dates and policies for airline tickets, conferences, tours, and other activities.

During spring break, many of you have personal vacation plans. If you are traveling, we encourage you to stay current with the latest travel advisories and the specific status of your travel location. The

CDC and the Department of State travel pages have reliable and accurate information. Travelers will be subject to any restrictions and isolation requirements that pertain to the country from which they are traveling. Below are some actions to help mitigate travel-related issues:

li.span: Monitor
travel advisories.
Plan for long-term stays.
Communicate with your principal or supervisor regularly.
Welcome students back to school.
Be flexible with missed assignments.
Reduce stigma related to travel locations.
Manage fear and misinformation.

p.span: In schools, we must continue to demonstrate compassion and care, as our greater community navigates this global health situation.
We would never want any of our students to be singled out or mistreated based on their ethnicity or where they have traveled. This is unacceptable and contrary to our values.

Help us prevent discrimination or stigmatization by sharing accurate information. COVID-19 infection is not connected to any race, ethnicity, or nationality. Misinformation about this virus or its spread can create fear and hostility that harms people and makes it harder to keep everyone healthy.

In an extreme situation, the District may need to close for a time. If a closure takes place, we want everyone to be prepared. ASD has an Infectious Disease Plan in place that will guide the response. That plan can be found at
ASD’s COVID-19 landing page.

If the District were to close, the effects to families and staff would be significant. Employees should take the time to consider how a potential closure would impact their daily lives and take steps to plan ahead. Childcare, work/activity schedules, and other logistics are a few areas that may be affected if ASD is forced to close. In the event of a closure, many District functions will still continue. Be open to remote work opportunities as needed.
Engage e-learning opportunities (school dependent).
Plan for persona absences outside of ASD closure.
Maintain facilities so they are ready when the District reopens.

p.span: You may find these websites useful in your effort to stay informed:

span.a: Alaska Department of Health and Social Services

a.title: Original URL: https://www.cdc.gov/. Click or tap if you trust this link.

p.span: I’ve also attached several helpful informational resources to include a very cool handwashing video created by Certified Nursing Assistant students King Tech High School. I hope you find them useful.

ASD will continue to keep you updated. Thank you for everything you do for students and families across the District. Have a restful and well-deserved spring break. We look forward to everyone’s safe return.
Sincerely,
Deena M. Bishop, Ed.D.
Superintendent, Anchorage School District
5530 E. Northern Lights Boulevard
Anchorage, Alaska 99504
Office Phone (907) 742-4312

h1.span: Mar. 04: ASD/Family Action Plans

div.p: Dear ASD Families,

The coronavirus, known as COVID-19, is a significant topic of concern in Anchorage and globally. While Alaska presently has no confirmed cases of this illness, the possibility remains real. To that end, please know your District is prepared. Here is helpful information for you to make informed decisions.

Prevention Measures - The best defense against any contagious illness is frequent and effective handwashing. Based on guidance from healthcare professionals, masks are not allowed unless specifically coordinated with the school nurse, as they are generally not used appropriately by children.

ul.li: Wash hands frequently
Use soap & water for 20 seconds; sing “Happy Birthday” or the “ABCs” to time the task
Use hand sanitizer when water is unavailable
Practice coughing/sneezing into the elbow or a tissue
Keep hands below the chin
Keep children home when sick
Teach proper hand washing
Purchase hand sanitizer for use in schools
Suspend handshaking routines
Increase sanitization of schools and buses
Educate all staff on current protocols
Suspend attendance awards
Encourage staff to stay home when sick

div.p: District Closure Preparation - ASD has an Infectious Disease Plan in place, and school nurses have the most up-to-date information. In an extreme situation, the District may need to close for a time. If a closure takes place, we want everyone to be prepared.

If the District were to close, the effects to families and across the entire community would be significant. Families should take the time to consider how a potential closure would impact their daily lives and take steps to plan ahead. Childcare, work/activity schedules, and other family logistics are a few areas that may be affected if ASD is forced to close.

ul.li: Plan for short and long-term closures
Work schedules
Childcare
Activity Schedules
Know how to reach your child’s teacher(s) via email
Communicate regularly with our community
Email
ASD website
Social media/text
Local media
Engage e-learning opportunities
Coordinate continuation of meal service for students in need
Plan for employee absences
Maintain facilities

div.p: Travel Considerations - Due to the risk of contracting the virus or being isolated outside of Alaska, ASD has canceled all school sponsored domestic and international travel for students and staff through April 2020. In-state travel is not affected.

During spring break, many ASD families have personal vacation plans. We encourage them to stay current with the latest travel advisories and the specific status of their travel location. The CDC travel page has reliable and accurate information.

ul.li: Monitor travel advisories
Plan for long-term stays
Check regularly for school updates and/or assignments
Inform your school of absences (stipulate illness, travel restriction, or isolation)
Communicate regularly
Welcome students back to school
Reduce stigma related to travel locations
Be flexible with missed assignments
Manage fear and misinformation

div.p: You may find these reputable websites useful in your effort to stay informed:

ul.li: Anchorage Health Department
Alaska Department of Health and Social Services
Center for Disease Control

div.p: ASD will keep you updated with new developments. Thank you for your continued engagement and cooperation.
Sincerely,
Anchorage School District

h1.aria-label: Mar. 02: All school-sponsored domestic travel canceled for March and April
h1.span: Mar. 02: All school-sponsored domestic travel canceled for March and April

div.p: Dear ASD Families & Staff,
As concern over the coronavirus, or COVID-19, grows across the United States, ASD has been fully engaged to ensure the welfare of our students, staff and community.

Due to the risks and the continuously changing situation, ASD is canceling all school-sponsored domestic travel for students and staff through April 2020, and we are canceling work-related, non-essential travel for ASD employees for the same timeframe. We have already canceled all school-sponsored international travel through April. At this time, travel within Alaska is not affected.

I want you to know that I do not take this decision lightly. This is hard business, and I am fully aware of how this impacts our students and our families. I am sorry for that. In taking this action, my leadership team and I have taken several factors into account:

ul.li: More than 50,000 students and employees pass through our doors each day. We have a responsibility to our students, staff, and the entire community to mitigate against the spread of this illness.

We must consider the risk to students and staff of being exposed to COVID-19. In traveling from Alaska, most flights connect through the major hubs of Seattle, Portland, and Chicago, which all have confirmed cases of COVID-19. Many trips involve large gatherings of people from all over the world, including sporting events, conferences, concerts, and tourist destinations.

We must also consider the possibility of our staff and students being isolated or quarantined outside of Alaska. As we have seen recently, a lot can change in a day or two. The risk of becoming stuck without sufficient support is very real.

div.p: My staff and I will re-evaluate school-sponsored and employee travel for May and the summer as the situation develops. I encourage families to stay informed on this rapidly changing issue. The Anchorage Health Department and Alaska Department of Health and Social Services websites are great references to consult.

We will send a follow-up letter later in the week with updates and tips on prevention and preparation up to and including school closure as a last resort. Until then, please feel free to contact your school or my staff with any questions. Thanks as always for your continued commitment and support in keeping our students and community safe.
Again, I regret the hardship this decision has caused. Please know that my decisions are always grounded in my intent to ensure the welfare of the students and families of our great community.

Sincerely,
Dr. Deena Bishop
ASD Superintendent

h1.aria-label: Feb. 28: All school-sponsored international travel canceled for March and April
h1.span: Feb. 28: All school-sponsored international travel canceled for March and April

div.p: Due to the increased global spread of the coronavirus (also known as COVID-19), ASD is canceling all school-sponsored international travel during March and April 2020.

The District will re-evaluate international travel for May and the summer based on how this situation develops. The District will also look closely at school-sponsored domestic travel based on developments in the United States.

The onset of spring break brings a significant increase in school-sponsored and family travel both domestic and international. Under the current circumstances, this travel presents two significant risks to our students and staff. First is the risk of travelers being exposed to COVID-19. The second is the risk of travelers being quarantined in a foreign country.

ASD encourages families and employees traveling to be mindful of the current travel advisories found on the U.S. Department of State and the Center for Disease Control websites. The District also encourages travelers to take appropriate measures to reduce exposure during their travels.

h1.span: Feb. 26: Message from the Superintendent

div.p: Dear ASD families and staff,

As everyone is aware, the spread of the coronavirus, also known as COVID-19, continues to be a topic of great concern across the globe. The District takes this potential threat very seriously, and I want to assure the community that we remain engaged and are prepared to respond should this virus make it to Alaska.

Alaska currently has no confirmed cases and has no persons under investigation of COVID-19. In the event that this virus does make its way to Alaska, ASD is prepared. Our school nurses are fully up to date with the latest information and protective gear, and they know exactly what to do should they have a suspected case in a school.

Additionally, ASD has an infectious disease plan, developed in cooperation with municipal, state and federal agencies, that will guide our response. If and when the District is required to put this plan into action, which could involve closure of all District schools, I can assure you the entire ASD community will be fully informed.

In the meantime, I encourage you to stay up to date on the latest developments with COVID-19 at the Anchorage Health Department web page or CDC website. Both sites have a lot of good information to answer your questions and hopefully allay your concerns about the risk in Alaska. My staff is also available to answer any questions you may have.

I understand the concerns that have been voiced throughout the community. ASD will continue to monitor this situation closely until this issue subsides. As your superintendent and a parent, I am fully committed to our students and our staff. We are in this together. Thank you for your patience and your continued support, as we educate all students for success in life.
As we say every day in our schools, good hygiene and thorough, regular handwashing continues to be the best defense against infection.

Sincerely,
Dr. Deena Bishop
Superintendent
